description:
Exceptional SF bistro on Sutter in the financial district.  Huge selection of French and California wine, exceptional French plates and cheese plate.  Wonderful service.

Funky decor, relaxed, not crowded at night!
author: Paul S.

description:
Feels like you landed on the set of "Friends" combined with a wine store.

Duck Ruben is not the dream I hoped it would be. I was disappointed by the small quantity of meat (duck and pastrami) compared to bread: only two thin slices of flavorless beef pastrami with a small layer of duck on this sandwich for $17. It was dressed weakly (probably intentional so you don't lose the duck flavor from the small portions). The buttered bread was great, but what a disappointment overall. I'd skip this if you are a sandwich nut.

Happy hour is decent. Deviled eggs are great and they have yummy leek crunchies on top. Cheese selection seemed ok and was $7 per portion. Glasses of wine start at $9. Staff was generally nice, but overly busy during lunch.
author: Billy D.

description:
Aquitaine is a sweet little French bistro at the bottom of Nob Hill in the financial district.  With a tiny storefront and a very deep bay. it is east to blow past.  We had found the restaurant on Yelp and had made reservations for lunch, so we were actively seeking it.  Otherwise, I would have missed it.

The restaurant has a very provencal feel - it is yellow (with yellow lights too that are just terrible for those Instagram shots IMHO) with mostly communal tables that have the classic French bistro look.  While we had reservations and expected to have a low table for just our party, it was more of a reservation at any table that happened to be available (surprising when you have five people).

The wine list is generous with many choices.  Fortunately, the servers are knowledgeable and forgiving.  The first wine that had was self selected and was absolutely wretched.  Our server asked what I liked and he found me a quick replacement.  The other wines selected by friends were done with guidance and these as well as my replacement were all quite good.  It is fun and different to find French wine in the land of California wine.

The food was generally very good.  The salmon special was not - the fish was very poor quality and lacking in any flavor.  However, the other dishes, from a classic Croque Monsieur to an inventive Duck Reuben, were excellent.  I had the Ratatouille special, which was an exquisite presentation.  Arranged veggies with a low and slow sauce are oh so expensive, but these were out of this world.  I devoured the ring of grilled veggies (tomatoes, yellow squash, zucchini and eggplant) encircling a roasted peppers and tomato pieperade.  Twas delicious and worth a return trip.  Similarly, the sandwiches used quality ingredients - hearty bread with good meats and cheeses.

Overall, I very much enjoyed my meal.  I felt sorry for DM who had gotten stuck with the poor salmon that was edible but lacking, and I was disappointed by the communal set-up, but I was a fan and would recommend it to others.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I found out about this place because I was looking on OpenTable for restaurants with private dining. We decided to give this place a try before we booked the private dining for our event and we LOVED this place! The food is excellent, the space is very intimate, and the service was exceptionally friendly. I didn't think restaurants in the FiDi area could really be that great because they mostly cater to working people who are forced to eat nearby, but this place is a true gem!

For appetizers, we tried a melon salad and the deviled eggs. For entrees, I tried the mussels while my partner tried to cheese and meat plate. The mussels were really tasty and the portion was large. We also tried their Ile Flottante. Everything was excellent. What's even better is that I found their prices to be very reasonable. 

I'm really excited to come back for our private event in December!
author: Jennifer W.

description: Great atmosphere and fantastic food. Service is good as well I am a vegetarian and they were very accommodating. I will definitely come back!
author: Raitis S.

description:
The five stars is specifically for the beet salad and burrata/prosciutto plate I had. They were both delicious. The burrata itself actually wasn't five stars but everything together was awesome. I had the two as my main. If you were two people, sharing one as a starter would probably be good. 

Party of 1 on a Thursday: didn't need a reservation but the place is basically full, including the bar!
author: Caitlin B.

description:
I ADORE AQUITAINE!  Anyone in search of a great, low-key dinner / wine / bites kinda spot, this is for you!

French, sultry, dimly lit, well-worth-every-bite. No pomp and circumstance here (Ahemmm...I point you to my previous review).  I found this experience to be so authentic, so delicious, all with polite, prompt service. 

So speaking of service, let's get it going.  As we were standing outside on a Friday night viewing the menu, the host invited us inside.  SCORE!  I already knew this was my kinda place.  As soon as we entered, he offered us something to drink...and a little bubbly it was :)  

Moving onto food...Simple, loaded with amazing flavor, delectable. I let our friend know that I was a vegetarian.  Eggs and cheese ok, but no chicken, fish, or broth.  He was 100% on my side :) . So he suggested the deviled eggs, which are AMAZING!  And the fries are cooked in vegetable oil - YAAASSSS!  A beautiful beet salad and a Fromage dish were the perfect additions to a shared situation for two.  

The ambiance here sealed the deal for me.  It's so low-key sophisticated, I loved every thing about it.  

Authenticity DOES still exist here in SF!!
author: Angella S.

description:
Went here for a business lunch. The place was a bit tight, dimmed, and echo a lot so it felt a bit loud despite the restaurant was only about 70% full during the time I was there.

I had the duck confit salad. The duck meat was shredded, it had good flavor but the salad was a bit pricey for the $19 price tag.

Business lunch partner had the fried chicken plate, the plate looked small but it was a good portion for lunch,  I guess. 

Overall, it was alright, but not a place I would frequent due to the price tags, ambiance, and menu options.
author: Yun C.

description:
Lovely little french cafe. It's dimly lit, but can equally serve as a romantic setting or even business lunch. 

I've had the mussels and the croque monsieur here. Both really great and a very large portion. Huge wine list and great service!

For the good food, it's strange that I've never really seen it crowded. Which is nice because tt's never been an issue for me to get a reservation - I've booked at 12pm one day prior with no problem. Aquitaine usually tends to be my fallback spot if I can't get a reservation anywhere else. (Which is not to say that it's my "last resort"- not at all!)
author: Jacqueline V.

description:
I'm only in SF a few times each year, but whenever I have the opportunity, I do my best to book a lunch group here at least once a year.

However, there is no way you would have known that by the way I was greeted when I arrived. Our waiter/host interacted with me like a long lost friend - fun, helpful, familiar. He immediately got us seated, proactively explained certain dishes and provided us excellent guidance. 

We ordered some starters and a few glasses of wine that came out quickly, with our entrees perfectly timed to follow. Our used dishes and plates were swiftly moved off our table to keep it from feeling cluttered but without us ever feeling rushed. 

Of what we ordered, the Duck Reuben was my favorite (although I'm glad we split it since it's a tad rich and heavy.) Runner up dishes included the Prosciutto and Peaches, Pommes Frites and the mixed charcuterie board. 

Aside from the delicious food and wine, the restaurant is still as charming as ever, with a festively cozy ambiance. 

Additionally, another thing that I really appreciate about this place is how quickly they can get you in despite a heavy lunch crowd. With reservations, I've never had to wait to be seated and they're always happy to bring you the bill whenever you need it. With a lunch of typically 1.5 hours, including a mile walk round-trip, I've never felt concerned that service would cause me to run late. 

And for that  (among many other things) I'm ever so grateful!
author: Tara L.

description: Good food in large quantity. One of these older places that I've never noticed - turns out it retain it's quality - traditional cooking done and served right.  Love the sandwich bc they heat it up with butter first. Delicious sauces. Looking forward to coming back.
author: Gloria T.

description:
3.5. My first experience here with work colleagues was great. We shared a lot of plates and there were lots of memorable bites with the duck reuben, poulet croustillant (the cabbage underneath the fried chicken was what did it for me) as well as the burger topped with duck shallot confit - so much flavor! The garlic pomme frites were incredible too. 

I liked the experience so much I came back for lunch with a friend a few days later and that experience was only a 3. The Poulet Croustillant did not taste as good. The chicken was overly crispy and did not taste super fresh. The garlic pomme frites didn't have a heaping of garlic in them as they did the first time. The meal was AOK, but I wouldn't have gone out of my way to come here again.

So I'm not sure where the inconsistency stems from. The Duck Reuben was still very good the 2nd time, so if anything - you can stick with that!
author: Alex L.

description:
I recently dined at Aquitaine with a work lunch group during our annual conference. Shout out to Tara L for picking this adorable and delicious place.

The restaurant takes Yelp Reservations, which is great when you are on a  time limit to get back to work. As you walk in, you're greeted with extremely friendly service, and feel right at home in this dimly lit den surrounded by wine. Cheers to great ambiance, and a wine bar that can feed you so well in under an hour.

Thankfully all of us were in the mood to share things, so we ordered quite a bit. 
-Charcuterie Plate: definitely order this, it's a mix and match of whatever they decide to bring, but we had a soft brie that was to die for.
- Salad - we got both prosciutto and pear and a green salad lightly dressed with anchovy.
- Burger - this was my favorite dish of the day. It's topped with Duck shallot confit and so rich.
- Duck Reuben - close runner up for favorite dish of the day. The duck confit they use here is soooo flavorful.
- Poulet Croustillant - this fried chicken was amazing. Crispy, yet juicy - it was definitely a crowd pleaser with everyone wanting one more bite. 
- Pomme Frites - sounds simple, but you must get these. They come in a dutch clog which is of course super fun, but the real fun begins when you dip them in the Sauce Ravigote. I had to look this up after eating here because I was obsessed - turns out its a french sauce filled with capers, herbs, and of course - mayo. YUM!

I must say, the French just know how to serve up amazing eats. Our group thoroughly enjoyed every bite, and sip (because we did get a nice glass of wine to pair with the meal). Our glasses were always full, and the food came out perfectly paced for our large, hungry group.

A cozy spot that is not to be missed! C'est magnifique, Aquitaine.
author: Diandra L.

description: I had to arrange a large dinner (22 people) for my department at work and Aquitaine was very helpful, responsive, and accommodating. My [very picky] boss and everyone in attendance said it was lovely, nice location, and yummy food. So if you're looking for a place to host a large party - this is a great option!
author: Salma N.

description:
really love this place. french cafe-style, small but not cramped inside. they have an excellent wine list, including bottles for purchase which aren't marked up to typical restaurant prices. they also have a decent beer selection, including Delirium Tremens (bottle) which is my favorite Belgian beer

very typical french bistro menu: mussels (excellent), hamburger, croque monsieur pomme frites, etc. they have a duck reuben which is very good.

I've been here for lunch three times recently and will definitely return again and also for dinner. it's a little more expensive than you'd want to spend for an every day lunch but the value is worth it as a treat. you won't be disappointed!!
author: Bob U.

description:
I loved this restaurant! It was such a good find from one of my colleagues. We went here this past week for lunch with a group of 6. My colleague had called in advance to setup a reservation, and we were ready to be seated upon our arrival - no waiting at all....score! 

We decided to share a variety of items off of the menu rather than ordering separate dishes per person. It was a great idea, as we were all able to sample a little bit of everything on the menu. We ordered the following items:

1. Charcuterie - Seems pretty basic, and I normally don't like ordering this at restaurants especially since this is the only thing I can probably do at home without messing it up! To my surprise they had some interesting options on the charcuterie board. There was a cheese which seemed like a crossover between feta and brie which was so delicious! 

2. Pomme Frites - The fries came in a dutch type of shoe, which was odd, but somehow adorable. Fries are another favorite thing of mine to eat - I couldn't get myself to stop eating these fries! 

3. Aquitane Burger - The burger was cooked really well. There was a ton of caramelized onions on the burger, which is a plus in my book! 

4. Duck Reuben - I've grown to love duck within the past few years, and was super excited to be trying this. It was delicious!

5. Fried Chicken - Definitely my favorite dish from everything that I had tried on the menu. The chicken was so moist on the inside and nice and crispy on the outside. 

The ambience of the restaurant was great! It almost felt like I was at a cute cafe in Europe, which I just absolutely adore! The waiter was so incredibly great to us throughout the course of our time there. He made sure everything came as fast as possible, and constantly checked up on us to see if there was anything else we needed. 

I'm so glad I discovered this place! Thanks, Aquitaine for the amazing food and service!
author: Margaret P.

description:
I got the roast beet salad with duck to go.

The beet was delicious, and the duck tasted nice and fatty. Serving size was small to medium. There were 4-5 slices of duck. Definitely not as big as a salad you'd get from Mixt or other salad place. 

The atmosphere seemed classy. 

With that said, for $24 after tax for a salad, it's hard to argue a case for returning. But it's certainly worth a try.
author: John L.

description: Such a wonderful place! Really great ambience and sitting areas. The food was delicious and the staff was incredibly friendly and gave some great wine recommendations.
author: Rio R.

description:
Cool french bistro and wine bar. I came in for a quick lunch during work. I ordered the duck Reuben sandwich and french fries.

Service was friendly and its perfect atmosphere for a date. My fries arrived first served in a large wooden boot which was an interesting touch. They reminded me of an upgraded version of 5 guys fries from the shape, cajun spices, and massive shareable size. The sandwich was tasty the star was the super hearty toasted bread. The cheese, corned beef, and bits of duck added good flavors to the thick crunchy bread. To my pleasant surprise it came with a salad of greens tossed in light oil. The meal was filling enough on its own with the big order of fries but no regrets here.

Good spot to checkout if you like french food or wine in a nice atmosphere.
author: Sean G.

description: This is our most recent go to for team lunches.  The food is good and the wait staff attentive and really nice.  We tried just about everything on the menu for lunch and it's all really good.  The fries are amazing.
author: Tracie P.

description: The duck Reuben was amazing. Definitely the best sandwich I've had in a long time. Great flavour and also a little sweet which is to my liking. Seems like everyone else loved their dish as well. We also got a cheese and pastrami board which was fun to try. The service was great and would love to come back and try another dish.
author: David W.

description:
Came here for a farewell lunch for one of my coworkers. The service would be slow by American standards but I think they're intentionally more French in their service. Everyone else liked their food. The main veg option is a polenta dish, mine didn't have mushroom like the menu said... the taste was fine but it just doesn't have a lot going for it from a texture perspective - it's just all mushy. :\ Also, they kept messing up orders for our table - two out of six people were served the wrong dish and they forgot something I had ordered.

Not bad, but since I'm vegetarian, I won't be back.
author: Annie J.

description:
Solid place but many of the dishes tasted too similar in their flavour profile.


---- FOOD ----

Tarte Flambé: 4.5 stars

Tempura Brussel Sprouts: 2.5 stars
Undercooked, hard and bitter. I think Brussel sprouts need a sweet sauce to counter their bitterness. Even worse move, it came garnished with arugula which is also bitter. The sweet sticky soy sauce works better.

Rosemary Polenta: 3.5 stars
Good and creamy, the parts that weren't doused in balsamic vinegar that was soaked up by tomatoes

Pork Ribs: 4 stars
Super tender meat, just needed better sauce. Served with persimmon slaw.
author: Letitia L.

description: Aquitaine is the pivotal classic French bistro with a casual feel to their food and an American twist to some of their dishes. I am big on French cuisine so I absolutely had to come here. Arrived for lunch one day with a co-worker to the amazing scent of fresh foods and daring flavors. This place is great for lunch as it is not overly packed. This place was a tad pricey but the taste was way worth it. I am a huge fan of duck so I ordered the duck Ruben and their soup du jour as my appetizer. The soup was a classic purée style and was very consistent. The duck Ruben absolutely knocked it out of the park. I felt like my protein was so fresh and delicious it quacked at me a few times. Delicious French roll sliced for the bread was buttery and toasted to perfection. Highly recommend this dish and this spot for lunch!
author: Chris O.

description:
I can't believe I've never been here before! I stopped in yesterday for a couple of glasses of wine and some food and was charmed by this little bistro. It's an amazing place in the Financial district for lunch, dinner, or happy hour.

Happy hour is from 3-6 and includes a great selection of food to nibble on and $2 off wine and aperitifs.

I love the atmosphere as it's intimate and charming with plenty of bar seats, high boy tables and a few larger tables both inside and out.

They have an arming selection of wines from France and the bartender was very knowledgeable and made excellent recommendations.

There is a different menu for lunch and dinner. I opted for the roasted beet salad which was decision and artfully presented. I also had the Escantoun landais, a rosemary polenta with Pyranees cheese and mushrooms which was to die for!!

I'm going to make this my go to spot in the FiDi for food and drinks going forward. You can purchase bottles of wine to go at 30% off, as an added benefit.

I love Aquitaine and highly recommend the bistro for the food and wine and atmosphere.
author: Emily C.

description: Nice, dimly-lit, friendly wine bar in FiDi and close to work. Came here for happy hour with some coworkers, and the staff was extremely accommodating and nice. I would come back again just to catch up with a friend over a glass of wine; very romantic atmosphere as well. :)
author: Lillian C.

description: Overpriced.  You have to order everything separately, so the cost climbs quickly.  Wine by the glass is expansive and expensive.
author: Dean M.

description:
I've passed Aquitaine many times.  It's beaming yellow sun, painted against a Mediterranean blue sky, beckons from afar.

I didn't have much time, so I used #Allset to reserve and pay for my meal ahead of time.  Love this service!

I tried my favorite, Croque Monsieur.  The toasted brioche crunched lightly and the ham flaked delicately with each savory, creamy bite.  It came with a salad dressed with a simple vinaigrette, tiny pink shallots clinging to fresh, mixed greens.

Warm ochre lighting lent an inviting glow to the farmhouse brown wood and antique metal decor.

Cozy, friendly vibe, good for a business lunch, besties date, or by yourself at the bar counter.
author: Sondra H.

description: Came here for a work lunch and they accommodated all 12 of us. Most folks got the duck rueben and I heard lots of "mmm" that followed. Cool dish! I got the ratatouille which was incredible. Came in an old cast iron skillet and was delicious from start to finish. The charcuterie was good too, pretty solid selections throughout. Can't say anyone had a bad dish. It's a bit on the expensive end, but that should be expected for a french place. Also dish sizes were a bit small, but again, expected for France right? Want to dip into the wine selection next time.
author: Jason P.

description: Waiters will give you tastes even if you only order wine by the glass. And they know their wines. To call Aquitane a wine bar is an injustice as they serve full meals. Which we   managed to avoid. There's plenty of good appetizers. The fries are a very nice big serving- and some of the best ever. Ask for bread. It's  a country style bread and you get lots.
author: Roopinder T.

description: Incredible food. Had an appetizer with cheese, cracker, meat, and fruits followed but the muscles and chirizo. Accompanied with a red blend  haven't had food this good anywhere outside of Europe before!
author: Jeff M.

description:
I feel a little guilty about giving 3 stars, so I'm going to stick with 3.5 stars. The reason is because of the excellent service but slightly disappointing food. Some friends were in town, and I was naturally tasked with finding a restaurant for dinner and making reservations. Wanting to try out a new place, I decided on Aquitaine. There's an old, European feel to the place when walking in. Wine bottles line the walls, and the lights are dim. Good way to escape the ghost town of the Financial District on a weekend evening.

Our waiter was fantastic with a wine recommendation, and he was attentive all evening. The chef was wonderful too, providing a complimentary shoe of fries, which we were erring on the side of not ordering. They were good! A little thinner and more cooked than I would have liked, but it was a sweet gesture. Overall there was such a comfy and welcoming feel. 

However, we were here for good food, and I felt that the duck dish that I ordered could have used a little more flavor on the meat. The vegetables that accompanied were similarly dull. Looking at more photos of the food here, it seems like the duck reuben sandwich is a popular option for a weekday lunch. I would love to try that in the future! It also seems like a low key place to have a few glasses of wine while enjoying a charcuterie platter.

Honestly the branding and colors of the awning have always turned me off to wanting to walk into this restaurant as I pass by, but I must say that I was impressed by the service of all the Aquitaine, and while I'm not interested in dining here for the food again, I would certainly love to stop by for their happy hour menu.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I came here to grab a drink with a co-worker after work. It's conveniently located in FiDi where I work so I appreciated the short walk. We sat at the bar and they were nice enough to let us sample a couple of wines before we made our decision. I just went for a rose and it was pretty good. It was a little sweet which I liked. It's a pretty cool spot - dimly lit, a bit upscale.

Overall, it's a decent place to grab a drink after work.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Went here with a biggish group of 8. We were able to get good recommendations on wine and every prepared dish was super good. The foie gras was very fatty and went real well with the jam and bread. They also can prepare your eggs deviled and there's a whole variety of fishy, smoky, salty, and peppery flavors in there.

For the main course, I got the duck which was super, super tender and juicy. I figure they must sous vide it because there's no way breast has ever been that juicy ;).

The desserts are big enough to share between two and the poached pear with ice cream on top of a fudgy browny really sealed the deal with a sweet and sticky finish. 

Go here if you're tryin to ball on a budget while still kind of ballin.
author: Ryuta O.

description:
We found this place kind of randomly, and were so happy we did! A small but solid menu. I had the escargot ravioli and shared the rosemary polenta with my mom. LOVED the polenta. Afterward we tried a small cheese plate, which was a lovely way to end the meal. 

Service was also very good--at the beginning the waiter misheard my order (I had ordered the ravioli and polenta to share with my mom, and he brought us two polentas instead). He fixed the mistake as soon as he could and didn't charge us for the extra polenta. 

Would definitely recommend and return.
author: Lauren S.

description:
This place was a nice escape for lunch during our work week! A lovely French vibe with lots of corks, barrels, and wine-centric chandeliers, it would be the perfect place for a lunch date or meeting up with a friend. We were seated at a round table, which I love for big groups since long tables sometimes cut off conversations. 

While plenty of things on the menu caught my eye, I opted for their Cucumber Soup* and Chicken Salad*.  The cucumber soup came out promptly, and while I wish there had been just a tad more Crème Fraiche, it was chilled perfectly, great consistency and plenty of little shrimp in the dish. Then came my hearty helping of chicken salad. This is no ice scream scooped chicken salad. You can tell it's made-to-order. I did ask for an extra thing of Grapefruit Vinaigrette since the chicken was just the tiniest bit dry for me, but this made it perfect! I love the crunch of the corn, and the smell of fresh arugula in this dish as well. 

Pomme Frites are $6 extra with any salad or sandwich with I think is a little on the pricey side, but they're not your average fries with fried garlic, pimenton, and sauce ravigote, and they come in a big Dutch shoe. We shared with the table so it worked out nicely! 

I'm a sucker for spots like this, and would definitely make my way back here on a future visit to San Fran. 

*Cucumber Soup - Shrimp, Crème Fraiche, Leeks, Fennel Fronds, Mint 
*Chicken Salad - Corn, Fennel, Avocado, Arugula, Shallot-Grapefruit Vinaigrette
author: Morgan F.

description:
Came here to meet up with a friend (old work colleague).  Cute little place and very good service.  Had the French music playing in background and I felt transported : ).  Wanted a light lunch so I ordered the vegetable salad with goat cheese - it was good, nice and lite but would have liked a little more goat cheese flavor to the dish but was not bad and would potentially order it again.  My friend ordered the burger and it looked amazing and she finished it off so must have been good (and also wasn't her first time
ordering it).  Waiter recommended a lovely merlot - blend rose which we both enjoyed.
author: Rachael C.

description:
Tried their duck rueben, which in and of itself deserves at least 3 stars, but the fact that it was actually very good - gets Aquitaine bonus points. 
Cool spot - recommend.
author: Oleg H.

description: I loved this restaurant! I found it in a travel guide on the best restaurants in San Francisco. https://www.sabrinamust.com/eating-your-way-through-san-francisco/
author: Rylie W.

description:
Aquitaine is quite leisurely, cozy and a charming spot to be at!

The ambiance inside, is dimly lit and outside has a couple of seatings, which is great for happy hours on a sunny day.

They have fabulous wine selections.  We ordered up the wine bottle that our waiter recommended - Chateau '09 red.  It complimented well with the cured meat slices and cheeses.  I love the charcuterie plate and pomme frites!

Our waiter got scolded at for not coming around to see if we are ready for the main courses that we ordered up.  It was uncomfortable to see, but I'm guessing it may be the French way of doing things?  We thought we were forgotten and by the time we finished our appetizers, we were too stuffed for the entrees.  The owner came around to make apologies for that part and provided us a lemon meringue to appease and sweeten the palate.  

Other than that incident, it was pleasant to be here for wine and dine!
author: Tiffany D.

description: A stumbled upon gen experience. Everyone in our group of five had a beautiful meal. The waiter was friendly, and relaxed. We ordered champagne for starters and his recommendation from their list of small producers was excellent, Jaquesson. The charcuterie plates was excellent. Beet salad was delicious. After wonderful main courses the desserts finished off a great meal. TRY THE ILE FLOTTANTE!
author: Hank H.

description:
I stopped by here while my friends and I were waiting to get a table at another restaurant. We all got a glass of wine, which is around $10-13, and pomme frites (which were SO GOOD). 

We were seated immediately at a table (even though we told them that we're just getting wine). The waiters were all really nice and professional and made sure we were happy. Service was a little slow in my opinion, but it seemed like they were kind of busy.

Would def come back for the fries!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Thirsty Thursday's are either your jam, or the one day of the week that you dread trying to find a decent watering hole that isn't standing room only or so loud you need to know how to read lips! I love a good session but let's be honest, it's Thursday, you still have to return to work level headed the next day. After walking away from my 1st choice due to aforementioned, my friend and I looked to Yelp (thank you!) and found this lovely  bistro nestled in the heart of bustling downtown.

Still filled with thirsters, the scene was definitely less boisterous and cramped. Seated at a small table for two near the window we ordered the 3 cheese charcuterie; Blue Cheese, Manchego and Brie. All excellent choices. The brie was one of the better selections I have had in a while! Along with the cheese came crisped bread drizzled with honey, honey covered grapes and some sort of hard nuts. I would have enjoyed some cornichons, but that's alright. The fresh bread was soft and delicious. 

While my friend enjoyed a glass of red, I opted for the cocktail of the day; Madam Eleanor. She was divine! Kava, Stawberry, Mint and Lillet Blanc. Apparently there are other ingredients but the barman was not at liberty to share. The secrecy made it all the more enjoyable as I tried my best to determine the 'other ingredients.'

Service was very pleasant. I'd like to try an entrée on my next visit.
author: Jaylena P.

description: Loved this little gem! When all else was closing and everyone was ready to go home, Leo, the bartender in this place said "sure, c'mon in!".   We had some amazing wine and even though the kitchen was closed, he made us a delicious cheese platter. A great experience, somewhat because of the wine and the cheese but mostly because of Leo and his hospitality and amazing attitude!
author: Martina S.

description:
Have you ever enjoyed a restaurant experience so much you wanted to move closer? This is the kind of place that would make me relocate to around the corner so that I could come there and be "NORM!" 

We were in the area for lunch and needed a place to hang until our meeting nearby. Andrew (owner, manager, sommelier, all around good guy) set us up at one of the high tops near the bar and took incredible care of us for the next couple hours while we camped out, ate, drank and enjoyed the energy. 

We had several items, including the Croque Tartine (with the egg - we're not barbarians) which was served with a side salad. The pomme frites in a shoe! One of the specials - which I didn't get to try or even see, since the person who ordered it downed it faster than the flash of a camera. I think he liked it. And our third diner had the burger. 

Everything was perfect. 

Andrew also told us about the space downstairs and although we were unable to partake of their fabulous wine list, we were enticed - to be sure. 

I cannot wait to go back - for dinner and a bottle or two! With friends!
author: Marilyn D.

description:
Andrew and staff created an awesome dinner for our group of 13.  The food was awesome and the wine is great too.  Everyone we interacted with smiled, chatted and helped us feel at home!

Thanks, I'll be back!
author: Bridget B.

description:
Aquitaine is a dimly-lit, friendly and romanticized restaurant in the middle of the financial district. The decor reminded me of Europe. They have a medium sized selection on their food menu but a large selection of wine. The servers were attentive and were willing to answer any questions. I did feel a bit rushed due to multiple waiters hovering over our table. But nonetheless, here is what we had for the evening:

1. Mussels Carbonade ($15) with Bacon, Cream, Pyrenees Cheese, Apples, Tartine
Amazing! It came in a huge pot that tasted extremely fresh with some bacon and sauce that unfortunately sunk to the bottom. So make sure to stir it up when you order this! They even put the bread inside so when they open up the pot, the bread is steaming and ready to be dipped!

2. Octopus ($15) with Warm Marble Potatoes, Fennel, Arugula, Pimenton Oil
The octopus was on the bottom of the plate when it was served to us (as you can see in the picture) But once we dug around, we were able to find the juicy steamed octopus! It was paired really well with the salad that comes along with the dish.

3. Blanquette De Porc ($26) Belly/Shoulder, Pearl Onion, Mushroom, Rice Pilaf
This plate came with a large portion of rice in the center with less of a portion of the belly and shoulder around it. But, the meat was very tender and juicy! I was able to slice through the meat like slicing through room temperature butter. 

4. Salmon ($26) French Lentils, Braised Leeks, Grapes, Beurre Rouge
We asked for the salmon to be cooked medium-rare but it came a little overcooked. The skin itself was crispy and salted well. If I were to come here again I wouldn't order this again though.

5. Tempura Brussel Sprouts ($9) Bacon Lardons, Sherry Vinaigrette
This wasn't something we initially wanted to order, but the waiter said that this dish pairs nicely with the belly/shoulder which I hate to disagree with. I think it was his selling point to have us try more on their menu, but I am thankful! The brussel sprouts were quite hard. I wished that it had been steamed a little longer before being put in the deep frier.

6. Red Ale ($8)
I'm a fan of ale. This one particularly had a chocolatey coffee taste. It was very bold and went well with the dinner. I know Aquitaine specializes in their wine, so I will definitely give it a try in the future. Oh! They do a 30% off bottles of wine if you take it to go!

I feel like this might be one of the best restaurants I've had so far in the financial district. Price-wise, it is about the same as any other in the area. But the belly/shoulder really blew me away. I feel like Aquitaine understands the art of food and seasoning and I appreciated dining there very much.
author: Linda K.

description:
Went here for drinks after work w a client. With looking for some snacks to accompany my wine. 

Unfortunately they had very limited menu for appetizers of any sort. We ended up just eating olives 

Suggestion, get some healthy alternatives for hors d'oeuvres i.e. hummus, chicken skewers, Etc.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Came here on a girl date with my wonderful ex-coworker last night. I had reservations for 6:30 p.m. We arrived a little early but were seated immediately. The atmosphere is very pleasant and definitely reminiscent of the bistros in Paris...simple, elegant decor with a sort of je ne sais quoi quality to it.  

Our waiter was very attentive (maybe a little too attentive). We started off with a couple glasses of wine (as if that needed to be mentioned) and a fromage plate with three selections of very French cheeses (you can tell by the slight ammonia aftertaste!). This is certainly not a bad thing if it is not overpowering but it is definitely an acquired taste. However, it seems that they have a wide selections of cheeses so if you prefer something more mild, I'm sure they can accommodate. 

For entrees, my friend had the salmon and I had the diver scallops. While the scallops were cooked and presented beautifully, I had a slight issue with it being presented on a bed of kelp. The smell of the kelp overwhelmed the other flavors in the dish and brought me a little too close to the ocean. I think the idea of the kelp is better in theory than in execution. Perhaps a more neutral-scented/flavored accompaniment might be a little more appropriate. That being said, the inclusion of diced watermelon and melon was certainly a refreshing take.

Overall, this is a great place to bring a date. It is casual but romantic and I will probably be coming back one day to try their duck!
author: Joan S.

description:
Brussels sprouts - bacon flavored and really good. 
Duck confit - it was great but also very rich. I think the duck and sausage combo makes it really heavy, but it's delicious!! Although, I'd personally try something else the next time I visit.
author: Soundarya C.

description:
I could tell Laurent Manrique owned this bustling French bistro on Sutter when I entered the door as he also owns the popular Cafe de la Presse across the Chinatown gate on Bush. Both not only look Parisian but feel Parisian, places you could envision on a side alley on the Left Bank in Montparnasse (photo: http://bit.ly/1SkXiCv). My good friend Carlos was in town and available for lunch on a Thursday, so I suggested it since it was close to my work even though I had never been. It's right near another pricier French restaurant Gaspar, which I'm sure doesn't help matters much for Aquitaine since San Franciscans, especially FiDi workers, are more into their burritos than their cassoulet.

Alas, it holds up pretty well if you want more French country-style fare. We started with their most expensive appetizer, the $22 Charcuterie, a wide-ranging tray of cured meat preparations and duck mousse with cornichons and Pommery mustard (photo: http://bit.ly/1OZCKvf). I rarely order such decidedly Gallic gourmet food, but it was easy for Carlos and me to share and it was quite good and filling, especially the richness of the duck which was complemented nicely by the generous basket of rustic French bread (photo: http://bit.ly/1PO8aIq). Carlos was smart to order the $15 Croque Tartine with Egg (photo: http://bit.ly/1nGxkN1). You can leave out the egg for $2 less.

It was an open faced ham and cheese sandwich but with French ham and Emmental cheese, a subtle yet savory Swiss cheese. The fried egg was nestled on top, and it was accompanied by a pile of mixed greens lightly dressed in a vinaigrette. For an extra $6, we ordered quite a pile of Pommes Frites, a bit too heavily crisped with aioli served in a wooden Dutch shoe (photo: http://bit.ly/1QAKDb1). I was a bit too ambitious in ordering the $22 Cassoulet, which was a hefty clay bowl of duck confit, Toulouse and garlic sausage, and white beans (photo: http://bit.ly/1UAG81e). It was steaming hot and bubbling over, too much even for me at lunchtime. You can definitely mangé until you're stuffed here if that is what you crave, mes amis.

FOOD - 4 stars...satisfying French fare, more peasant-oriented than Gaspar
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...a bit crowded and loud but very much Paris in spirit
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendlier than Paris
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice to have this option even with Gaspar Brasserie and Cafe Claude close by
author: Ed U.

description: Awesome low-key wine bar with a cozy feel and friendly staff! Loved the mussels, and the sommelier was very helpful. Can I also say their by-the-glass wine list goes on for days! For days! Glad I found it on my visit to SF, I expect I'll be back there soon.
author: Therese F.

description:
Located just a couple of blocks away from the hustle-and-bustle of Market and Montgomery Streets in San Francisco, Aquitaine veritably takes you away to the south of France for a wonderful, hearty French meal.

The wine list is extensive, especially for Bordeaux, and quite reasonably priced. The food is not knock-your-socks-off great but really very good and very well suited to the wines. Had a squash salad and while it wasn't what I was expecting, it did the job of giving me a full tummy. I'm not sure that I'd return here as nothing stood out as spectacular!

2016 Review #74
author: Stephanie G.

description: Happened on this place after a few hours of shopping and we LOVED it. Warm and lively ambiance, delicious food, and nice staff. We didn't eat any of the mains but chose instead to order 5 different appetizers and sides - the mussels, broccoli, polenta, fries and butternut squash soup. All were excellent and very flavorful. Highly recommend!
author: Makena S.

description:
Dining in this area as a non-tourist is kind of a nightmare and after having eaten at Aquitaine my feelings haven't changed one bit. 

The vibe on Wednesday evening was strange, the service was extremely uncomfortable, and the best dish of the evening between our decent-sized group was the side of polenta. 

The menu seems priced for tourists and very meat-heavy. If you're vegetarian you'll be left largely with just side options. The fries served in a clog shoe are fun but I'm not gonna come back to a place to eat out of a shoe. 

Our server was over-the-top with trying to up-sell. I think he was used to tourists who ask, 'what's good?', so he can recommend higher price-point dishes and multiple bottles of wine when they were not necessary. And I get that he wants us to tab up but this was more of a strong-arm situation than taking our order and made all of us uncomfortable enough that his incessant antics became the number one talking point at our table, which is rarely a good sign.

If I had to come back I'd get the polenta and fries but I don't anticipate returning because the dishes weren't stand outs enough to want to subject myself to what felt like my own server pan-handling at my table.
author: Candice G.

description:
Went here on a rainy Friday night when a sushi place refused me and my girlfriend food. Hungry for food and thirsty for wine we stumbled upon this quaint little restaurant. 

The staff was super kind and the manager/ owner himself came by and helped us pick wine. I had the ugna blanc which was lovely crisp and light while my friend got the Pinot noir. We decided the share a side and an entree and got the Brussels sprouts and duck confit. 

The Brussels sprouts was deliciously crispy and perfectly glazed with balsamic. So good. 

The duck confit was also so good but kind of on the heavier side. I felt the gravy was too salty and the beans made me feel so stuffed. The duck itself was beautifully cooked and melted in my mouth. 

I wish they had more vegetarian options but all in all it was delightful
author: Ashmita V.

description:
Cozy and tasty.  I felt like I had landed in an ancient Parisian bistro.  Lot's of great wine that you don't normally get your grubby mitts upon.  I had a delicious white from one of my favorite wine regions (Languedoc).  

The fish I had was so tasty...crispy skin, totally deboned sitting in a sweet and sour compote (tomato and mustard greens I believe).  I would definitely return.

At 25$ a entree for lunch, it is on the spendier side.
author: Dusty B.

description: We loved this place for dinner! It had awesome scallop dish and the servers gave us an incredibly on point advice on what wine to take with our dinner.
author: Surge T.

description: I had never really eaten French cuisine before so this was new for me. I'm glad I tried it out! Everything was succulent and the portions were large enough to have you feeling satisfied. We ordered the cheese plate (yum!) And the pomme frites. The fries come in a wooden shoe! Ha! Delicious. The lamb, halibut, and duck were moist. The staff was friendly and attentive. They were great at providing recommendations. Definitely will be back!
author: Katy Grace O.

description: Amazing restaurant!!  This little gem of a restaurant was outstanding! My husband and I were blown away by the cheese and charcuterie board. Our server was very knowledgeable and attentive. The atmosphere was warm and inviting! Also had their signature dessert which out waiter paired with a yummy white wine. I highly recommend this restaurant. We will be back!
author: Denise L.

description:
Best kept secret in the Financial District! I have been coming here since the first week they opened and always enjoy the wine, food and TLC service. 

My girlfriend and I came here last Wednesday night and our waiter, Leo took care of us! I needed help with the wine list and he suggested a dry French bottle that was perfect and not too pricey. 

Deviled eggs, greens, steak and quail put us in a great place! I have used this restaurant many times for work lunches as well. 

It's one of the few spots downtown that's actually good, not over-priced and easy to get a reservation. They also have a beautiful space downstairs I'll keep in mind the next time I'm hosting a big party for my team!
author: Alison C.

description:
The owner called me back, committed to resolve the problem. He refunded the cost of the scallops and offered to do what he could to right the situation. After offering his apologies, he suggested that I could have finished cooking the scallops upon arriving home. Hmmm.. Regardless of this addition, one thing is certain, the owner is committed to keeping up the strong appearance of his restaurant. And, to this, while the service and food was not the best during my visit, it certainly may have been on other occasions (as included on other reviews).

The two stars are for the original visit, as I cannot get over the fact that my wife nearly consumed raw scallops while nursing. However, i again think that this establishment has the potential to be something great if only its consistency in execution is as great as the followup of its owner.
author: Stewart A.

description:
I saw a lot of photos of the fries that come in a shoe, and - how was I not going to get it? But it was rather a disappointment :/ just regular and not crispy thick cut fries with minimal flavor. Big serving size, though.

I got the duck reuben, which was super good but pretty heavy for a lunch menu. I only got through half of it, and even that seemed to sit heavy for the rest of the day past dinner. 

It was not very crowded during lunch on a weekday, but the service was very spotty, and our group - a big group of 8-10 with a reservation, had a difficult time getting the waiters attention whenever we needed something.
author: Grace P.

description:
Ambiance and service is pretty on point, but the food was almost a hit-or-miss, but luckily, more hits than misses at least. This space has a charming feeling to it, though dark with a few candles lit here and there - this place would be great for a romantic dinner date. Started off with a drink - the Moulin Rose with Lillet, Apple Cider, Habanero, Mint. I love drinks that have an interesting twist to it, and in this case - the minty but spicy kick at the end of each sip. Refreshingly spicy!

For appetizers, we shared the Mussels and Fries, along with Frog Legs. SKIP the frog legs - we were all pretty disappointed in these, as it didn't taste like anything special nor was it as tender as it could have been. However, DEFINITELY share the mussels - the broth was so good, I could probably eat this all day and night. The fries were supposed to compliment this dish, but it was just alright.

For my main dish, I decided on the Crispy Cod, which was fried pretty well! Very think layer so it's not like you're eating a whole lot of batter. The fish was very moist and not overcooked at all. I also got a few bites of the Bison Short Ribs (rich and yummy) and the Steak and Potato (delicious too!).
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I've walked by this place a bunch before and the colorful awning always made me want to stop in. Today I finally dropped by for lunch and so glad I did!

The staff and the owner were incredibly friendly and helpful. I had a seasonal squash salad, and want to come back soon to try the duck sandwich and for happy hour.

Outdoor seating score: 4 
Several tables out front for days with nice weather.
author: E F.

description: Had lunch here.  Best mussels ever, excellent frites. Great service and huge wine selection.  Definitely coming back.
author: H W.

description:
The upstairs bar is kind of small but i'd hardly say it's too crowded. It also, has a downstairs portion which is very lounge-y. The bartenders are attentive and get your orders in pretty quickly if you are upstairs. Downstairs there isn't a bar, so you have to wait a while for a server.

The wines (i've tried both their merlot and cab) are good and I haven't tried any food. It is a good date night but it is definitely not a place to go out.
author: Neil P.

description: Charming French restaurant with a bistro atmosphere.  It was hard to decide what to order because there were so many delicious choices on the menu. I had the beet salad which is served with thin slices of duck. At a glance, it did not seem like enough food but by the time I finished, it was enough to keep me full for the rest of afternoon. The beets in the salad are the largest I have ever had and were very good. The shredded kale was lightly dressed. I liked the duck and just wished for a bit more. Friendly and efficient service. I will definitely be back.
author: Lucy L.

description: Every time I come here, the service is impeccable and the food even better. Their cheese platter is so good, it's hard to leave room for the main course!
author: Ashley W.

description: Loved the atmosphere and the friendly staff here. We went here tonight for a light bite. We got a charcuterie plate and tried out a few wines. Our waiter took the time to explain different wines to us and even gave a few tastings. Would come back again!
author: Jess S.

description:
I was visiting for the weekend and stumbled in to this fun wine bar! It was a great experience! 

The owner was so knowledgeable about all of his wines, they had wine to go as well!! 

I would recommend this restaurant for dates, friends and even big groups.

Keep it up!
author: Sammo C.

description:
If you like wine this is a spot for you! Even though we were there for lunch they kept offering us the grape goodness that they had in bulk supply! I had a work group go to lunch here and it was a jolly good time! They do not have much for vegans so I ended up with a pretty small salad, but it did have great flavor, I just needed about 4 of them! The rest of my table's meals look quite amazing ranging from a duck sandwich, to clams, to soup.. Everyone seemed pretty stoked and satisfied with their meals! 
Some one ordered a side of fries which actually was served in a wooden shoe? I felt like I was in a german bar with a boot of beer except it was fries! 

The staff was super nice and the layout of the place is cool, featuring mostly high top tables, perfect for party's of 2-5. Food comes out pretty quick and if they had a few more vegan options I would probably hit this back up at some point! 
Tip: order an actual drink if you are thirsty the water glasses they fill are tiny and they only fill them about half full.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Great ambience exceptional service. The food is perfectly paired with the exceptional French wine. Andrew the owner is very attentive to each of his guest. 
A must visit if you're ever in the SFO area.
author: katrien d.

description:
Good French dining in Fidi. Great service, good ambiance, and a lunch prices.

Ordered the duck confit with baked beans and sausage and it was very good. Duck was perfectly tender and full of french flavors. Very filling.

The mussels with wine and tomato are unique and tasty.

They also take reservations on Yelp, which is helpful. Would come back.
author: Chuck N.

description: Came here for one of my work's weekly Happy Hour events... and it was OK. We basically got everything on their menu. Their meat and cheese plates were nice, but at $28 a plate for 2 or 3 pieces of scallop and some pork belly, it wasn't anything special. If I could give 3.5 stars, that would be more accurate. Restaurant is cosy.
author: Sam S.

description: We stayed at the Hilton in union square so this place was a quick 10 minute walk. We were able to make a reservation easily. Hubby and I each had a glass of wine. We started with pommes frites which was a pretty large portion served in a shoe. We also had the deviled eggs and shared the pork ribs. I liked the ribs the least. It was a little dry and the slaw that came with it was way too creamy. It would've been better without all the mayo. For dessert we had the molten chocolate cake which had a gooey chocolatey lava. The service was great and it's definitely a cute place to have some wine.
author: Jennie C.

description: Awesome place! Staying in SF for the weekend and was looking for a place to have a glass of wine. Super cool atmosphere, great food, friendly staff who taught us a ton about French wine and let us taste different types, and overall good experience. Wasn't super busy either and a reservation wasn't needed, which was nice.
author: James P.

description:
French bistro that felt French but not pretentious. Took the missus here for lunch the day after Mother's Day and it was a big hit (with the wife, not on the wallet). 

Shannon had the croque tartine and I had the duck Reuben's but we switched half way through because the tartine was too good for me to resist. 

Then for dessert we had the ile flottante--the floating island. Holy cow! We almost floated away, it was such an unearthly delight. An ultra light meringue -- lightly poached egg white foam, really-- floating on a creamy vanilla custard. Wow. 

Too early for wine--although the wine list looked
great--so the entire lunch was around $40. 

Lovely decor, with a wine theme. Attentive but unobtrusive service. 

I can't wait to go back to try some other items we spied on the menu.
author: Matt A C.

description:
Looks are deceiving.  Especially when just reading the profile on Yelp.  
Given the crazy SF real estate and business costs, there are more bars than restaurants opening these days.  The demographic changed from local families or professionals to a younger party crowd that parties like it's 1999 every night... guess it should be 2099 now!
After searching on Yelp or a lunch meeting spot convenient from Union Square, Fidi, and Chinatown, this was my choice on a recent weekday.  Turned out, both of my guests dined here before and were familiar.  Reading the Yelp highlight section, I ordered a the deviled eggs to share which coincidentally came in threes.  Everyone enjoyed this as they disappeared in less than a minute as we discussed business.  One diner raved about their duck cassoulet, but they had only one order left.  The other guest had a burger which looked delicious.  Wanting the cassoulet, I deferred to my guest and chose the waiter/owner's (?) special recommendation of the halibut with polenta (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=kCxmDJxHpcd5LjxDbIIL-A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  Not being a polenta fan, I was skeptical whether I'd enjoy this.  This fish was deliciously grilled, crispy outside while soft and tender inside.  The big surprise was the polenta cakes which reminded me of crispy tater tots or hash browns that were creamy inside.  My friend's burger looked good, but nothing that really stood out.  The cassoulet portion was generous and that friend took leftovers home.
I must admit that this place was not what I envisioned.  It is a bit more casual, almost bordering on a cafeteria feel, than expected.  The food was solid and props to the guy who steered me to that halibut.  
It's a bit of a walk from my workplace in Chinatown, but would stop in and hopefully get a bite of that cassoulet next time.
author: Mike C.

description:
This place is truly a hidden gem in the financial district. They have revolving daily specials with French classics that frequent the menu. Some of the chef's are Michelin rated, and the staff and food provide and atmosphere that is unexpected for such a humble place. If you come in with minimal foriegn wine experience, PLEASE just trust the staff to lead you the right way. They will also let you sample so that you can find "your wine". This spot is great for lunch, happy hour and dinner. Quaint atmosphere and a loving staff (very European, so they may kiss you on the cheek ;) )
I am definitely a customer for life.
author: Shanna B.

description:
Excellent service and attention. And you can't go wrong with any of the wines on their list. Deviled eggs and frites were wonderful. The ambience is simply fantastic - and I like that the location is slightly off the beaten path on the weekends. 

4 stars given because our entrees left a lot to be desired, but they weren't terrible. I will be coming back for their happy hour.
author: Leah C.

description:
I always see this place when I walk to work. I would never think of coming here. Doesn't seem like a good place, but I was so wrong. We were going to host an event here and try out the food. It was so yummy, I came back and brought my friends. 

Smoked Tongue--Persimmon Carpaccio, Watercress, Sauce Gribiche-amazing. The persimmons with the beef tongue is amazing. Sweet and smokey. Don't be scared of the tongue. It's a thin slice of cooked beef. Not chewy at all.

Brie Sandwich--Granny Smith Apple, Fig Compote, Truffle Butter-comes wtih a small salad. This is what I came back for. It's so delicious, I want more!

The fries are excellent too. Great portions. 

I heard the Duck Reuben is what they are known for. Will come back again to try this.
author: Karen H.

description:
My colleagues and I stumbled upon Aquitane after a recent afterwork happy hour. It was about 7:30pm and all the restaurants in Belden Alley were either packed or looked uninviting. So Aquitane looked about as good as anything in the neighborhood. And best of all, it was open and not too crowded.

Our famished group of 5 was immediately seated at a nice round table (which is perfect for everyone to see and chat with one another). So everything was off to a promising start! But then our server greeted us, and then that's when things started to go down hill. 
Before we could even look at our menu, he immediately tried to sell us on a bottle of wine. When my co-worker mentioned that she was interested in drinking a red, he replied "So a bottle then? How many bottles for the table?" Whoa whoa whoa - slow down there, Speed Racer. No one said anything about bottles. I decided to order a glass of bubbles. Once again, the server asked if I'd like to order a bottle. In fact, it wasn't so much asking as it was automatically assuming. We then all put in our food orders. We were a very simple bunch this night. 4 burgers, an order of frites, and a side of polenta. The waiter didn't really hide his disappointment with our simple order. It was like you could see him calculating in his head how little money he was going to make off our table. When we all finished placing our orders, the guy then said "So shall I start you off with the cheese platter?" Again, not really asking, but inferring that this what we should be doing. We politely declined. "Ok, then how about an order or two of Deviled Eggs?"

I finally had enough of the hard sell and spoke up. "Excuse me, could you please just accept our order and stop up-selling us? We just want our burgers and wine. That's it."

The server seemed to get the hint and went off to the kitchen. 20 minutes later, we got our food. It was fine. I've definitely had better hamburgers. There was nothing exciting going on with this burger to warrant the $16 price. Furthermore, the hamburger bun was over-toasted (to the point where it was just crunchy bread). And the fries that accompanied the dish were quite limp. They could've used a few more minutes in the fryer. Though I did enjoy the dipping sauce that came with them.

All in all, this was a decent meal... but nothing to write home about. And the pushy waiter really tarnished the enjoyment of our dining experience. We came here for dinner, and not to buy a time-share. I guess the best way to sum it up is that they treated us like we were tourists who just didn't know any better.
author: Kevin B.

description: This place is wonderful. Gorgeous, wonderful good and wine, and the staff was amazing. Just go here!
author: Stefani C.

description: Went here for a work lunch with 5 people.I was a little disappointed that the waiter had to ask us to repeat our order 3 times because he forgot, but nonetheless, he was very cordial. Food was okay--I had the polenta and it was a bit watery, and the portion was far too small for a lunch entree.
author: Benjamin A.

description: It is the second time I have mussels here, different recipe, same pleasure! Their mussels are just exceptional! A very enjoyable experience.
author: Maya G.

description:
Work has been surprisingly super stressful lately, so I decided on a Friday, I needed to go out and have a drink and finish off this 7x7 list. 

Not that my experience was bad in any way, the servers and bartender was super nice. Also the atmosphere was decent - quiet and nice, with a large bar for people in a rush or people dining by themselves. There weren't even that many people in the restaurant, but just something about it.

I ordered the pomme frites in a shoe which is a great plating technique, fun and creative, but the fries and sauce were just not THAT amazing. Honestly, the fries and sauce that came with it are good, and would order again if I happened to be at the restaurant, but nothing that I would make a special trip for. The fries were different sizes - some were much thicker than the rest so some of them nice and thick cut fries that were somewhat crunchy on the outside and definitely soft on the inside. Others were thinner and too crunchy for me. I just wish there was a bit of uniformity. 

Overall, I really just had one dish here, so I can't really tell you what else is good or not. Wasn't the best thing I've ever had, but wasn't bad either.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday for dinner with a friend and the place is pretty much dead. Our busboy was very attentive and nice, but the actual waiter was more attentive to his phone than us. We had a hard time waving him down to get our bill, even though we're the only table eating at the restaurant.

I came here and had the deviled eggs. That was pretty fabulous, especially with the bit of duck on top. We then shared a salad, which was good. The night kind of went downhill from there. We shared the mussels and skirt steak and got a side of fries.

The steak was cold, but still good, but the mussels were tiny and it was really odd the way they mix the garlic bread into the dish instead of having it on the side. Maybe that's how some region in France do it, but I've never seen anything like it. Our fries were cold and limp and we basically didn't touch it. 

We also shared the floating island dessert. It was the most odd texture that I've had before, and it had this weird sour drizzle on top that totally ruined the creme anglaise. I don't think the meringue was actually a meringue, not sure what it was, but it was spongy and just odd.
author: Alice W.

description: A super cute wine bar tucked in the FiDi. The staff was very kind and patient, given that my friend and I weren't wine experts or in love with wine by any means. He helped make some wonderful recommendations and we had a great night knocking out several glasses of wine. I did not try to food but if you're ever thirsty during the week and are looking for a quiet place to unwind, I think Aquitaine would be a fun choice.
author: Helen F.

description:
Came here for a meal with some work colleagues and gotta tell you that I was pretty impressed with the service - the staff was very helpful and attentive. The ambiance is also a plus: the space is quite charming and cozy, and I think it must be even more special at night. Even their dishware is cute and funny, which is always a great way to catch the customer's attention.

The menu is not very big, so you gotta make your choice based on a bit of a small selection, or at least that's how I felt. I ordered one of the 4 main dishes, the Escantoun Landais (rosemary polenta, pyrenees cheese and cherry tomato). I found it to be pretty interesting and it was not bad at all, but I do feel it lacked a bit of flavor. It kind of felt like a boring choice I guess.

I had never had ginger beer before (sorry, I am Brazilian after all!) so I gave the one they sell here a try and hmmmm...let's just say it's way too sweet for me! Overall, I think this is a great place for a nice meal, but I liked the experience more than the actual food. Maybe next time I'll order a winner.
author: Gabriele J.

description:
We had a fun night here for dinner catching up with friends in SF. We sat at one of the high top barrel tables toward the back which allowed us to people watch.

Service was top-notch - friendly, knowledgeable and genuine. I started with one of their drink specials (Pomme something) and it was so good, I quickly ordered another with dinner. Wine selection is amazing too.

We shared the yummy fries and a flatbread to start - both of which were excellent. I had the salmon for my entree and was very happy. It was cooked well, had great flavor and great portion size with the accompanying potatoes.

I would definitely visit again and try more menu items.
author: Brandon C.

description: On this fine day in the City, Warriors up 2 and the Gigantes win streak at 5, I step into Aquitaine - a place that could be any sidewalk cafe but offers much much more.  My head is swimming through the varieties of wine on the shelves when the Somme casually saunters by and offers some direction. Chateau Fourcas Hosten is going down easy with the lamb. I wish I could spell the desert but the literal translation is island of deliciousness - I think. People around me are saying good things. The vibe is good. I'm looking forward to coming back on a warmer day to sit outside and watch life go by on Sutter. This place is one of the reasons I love SF - I could be in Spain or France and have the same kind of experience.
author: Jason H.

description:
**Summary**
Staff: Friendly, accommodating, A++
Ambiance: Romantic-ish wine theme
Food: My bri/apple sandwhich was AMAZING. Salmon was small. 

LOVED THIS PLACE. 

**Deets**
Came here with a coworker and had the special for the day, an apple and bri sandwich.  I was going to be good and get a salad but he guilted me into something more interesting. Oh man it was DELICIOUS.   Sorry if you're reading this and they don't have it, sucks for you, bro. 

Coworker got the salmon dish...smaller than expected (TWSS).  But I think he liked it?

We shared some fries.  THEY CAME IN A WOODEN SHOE.  Maybe all appetizers come in a shoe idk but get the fries just in case guys!!!!! They were fat and not too cripsy just I how I like my fries.  Served with a side of aoili. 

I would totally eat here again!!!  Would never have found it if it wasn't for my coworker, glad I decided to be social today. 

Thanks, Aquitaine.
author: Christina L.

description:
I came here with the purpose of having Il Flottante for dessert. In my mind, whatever I would have prior would be just fluff. And I'm not talking about the super fluffy meringue of an il flottante dessert.

They have a nice HH menu of appetizers and drinks ($2 off for HH). 

Food: Charcuterie and cheese board was nice. Two different types of sliced salamis and one brie-like cheese and a harder cheese. Big slices of crusty bread. Accoutrements of bruleed grapes, whole grain mustard, and some type of brittle. I thought the brittle was interesting because I've never seen brittle in a charcuterie board before. The brittle wasn't overly sweet and I suspect that balsamic vinegar was used in it's creation. Smoked salmon deviled eggs were delicious.

We shared the duck confit - Garbure. It was an interesting dish. White beans, cabbage, veggies, bacon, and a leg of duck confit. Poured over it was a type of white wine "soup". It wasn't my favorite thing and I probably won't order it again. Next time I'll try the bavette steak.

Service & Ambiance: The restaurant has a cute brasserie feel with chandeliers made of wine bottles and wine glasses. The manager came by to let us know that downstairs was a lounge and we were curious. They offered to bring our dessert downstairs. Really comfortable and quaint space. We hung out there for an hour just chatting because the couches were quite comfy.

Great place to unwind after work. I'll be back.
author: Viyada S.

description:
I've definitely had better tarte flambees and deviled eggs (3 halves for $6) but they were delicious. I especially enjoyed the cab franc ($14).  Bottom line: if you are looking for a nice glass of wine and some nice snacks to pair, and you don't mind paying a bit of a premium, this is the perfect spot. 

The downstairs area is much quieter, I love the availability of seating, space and optional outdoor seating. 

Service is polite but not particularly friendly. As expected from a French spot I guess.
author: Jess C.

description:
A lovely French style restaurant with an amazing collection of French wines. Wow, you must check out the wine wall. This is a wine connoisseur's heaven! There are so many lovely drops to choose from. 

The restaurant features a really cool bar towards the back of the restaurant, set up kind of like a street stall inside with terracotta tiles. The lighting is dim and creates a comfortable and intimate feeling even in the middle of the day. This is definitely a restaurant to visit for an informal dinner with friends or workmates that you want to impress. 

We were set up for a work lunch on a wine barrel table in the middle of the restaurant. It was not the most comfortable option, but I guess it was suitable as we were quickly dropping in for for lunch. 

I could not go past the Duck Reuben on the menu. I have never had a Reuben before, so was very excited to give this famous sandwich a go. And it was better than I imagined. Full of flavour with corned beef, cheese, dressing and slow cooked duck. It was such a comforting meal. Maybe not the best thing to eat in the middle of the day, as I wanted a nap afterwards.  But I think I had the best meal out of my companions. 

The service at the restaurant was very attentive and eager to please. They ensured that everyone was catered for and was happy with their experience. The obviously care a lot about their customers.
author: Anita D.

description:
Good place for a simple but elegant lunch. Chairs and walls are well-decorated, and usually this place is half full at noon. 

I had an entree with duck and bean, which tastes good and smells better. However their dessert plate was too large and carelessly made. (You would never want to try caramel cream cake)
author: Dingding Sherry W.

description:
Four stars because I really liked it.  Until I ate the mussels.  Yep, I got a couple of nasty ones, got raging, ugly sick, and am still recovering three days later.  Other than that, how was the play, Mrs. Lincoln?  Well, not bad.  I came on an after work Friday. The pomme frites are just as good as everyone says they are, and you can get a nice glass of wine for $10 - $13.  For an after-work drink-n-snack I thought it was great*.  More reasonable than other after-work drink options in the Financial District (far more reasonable than Hidden Vine, for example, although Hidden Vine is much nicer and trendier.)

* Except for the killer mussels.
author: Steve C.

description:
Well, one night I came in late after work, and took a seat at the bar. It was about 9:00 p.m. The restaurant was pretty empty. I asked if they had a wine like a Riesling-sweet with a little bit of carbonation. The guy at the bar said, "I only serve wines from the South of France." Hm. That's cool, because I only serve attitude from the West of Oakland. Friends, this is why I drink beer. 

I don't know what this kind of pretension accomplishes. Perhaps Aquitaine is the Abercrombie of wine bars and doesn't want any wine drinkers over a metaphorical Size 6. Or maybe that guy has to deal with people lacking wine knowledge all day long. Maybe his family was killed in a wine vineyard in the South of France. 

Despite this pretentious first impression, I have been back a few times since, and I've had a good time. Their menu has vastly improved since it first opened (it was pretty duck-laden at first). I like the small plates-everyone I know likes the deviled eggs, they have a really nice kick of spicy mustard. 

I've had a Rose and a few white wines here I've liked. But nothing that wonderful, despite their apparent South of France-ness. 

The staff is really nice notwithstanding my first visit. I really like the decor. There's a little sidewalk patio for when the weather is nice.

Overall, a nice little wine bar in the FiDi. Just remember to bring your South of France wine guide. And don't you dare ask for a Riesling.
author: Sunny S.

description:
My husband and I decided on last minute date night on Saturday, and of course getting a reservation sometimes makes you question if the place is good.  We arrived and there was only one table, ouch, we were nervous.

Our waiter reassured us that we were going to love our meal and that on week days the place is busy.  

It has a very French, neighborhood, bistro feel.  It's casual, yet warm and inviting, romantic and intimate, yet great for friends or dates alike.

We started with the foie torchon, unfortunately the sauce they paired it with absolutely killed it for me and overpowered the flavor.  It was horse radish base and way too strong, the cherries were mixed in so they got lost in it too.  Please do the traditional pairing.  

For the mains we had the burger and bison ribs, both were yummy and very French inspired.  The meat was tender, lean, pairing was great, sauce was hearty and paired nicely with a red wine, the burger was scrumptious as well.  Even our little dog loved the bison bone, yes we took it home and she had a blast.

I would definitely come back for an after work dinner, drinks or date night.
author: Inga W.

description: Valentine's Day 2017: I made a reservation weeks ago.  It took one hour to take our order, one hour for each course to arrive, and the busboy was the only one paying attention to us.  Everyone was angry at the wait and a few people even advised people coming into the restaurant to leave.  The food was overcooked and mediocre, at best.  $58 per person for a Valentine's dinner that still made me think to go to Taco Bell afterwards....  They were unprepared and short staffed.  I would NOT recommend going here.  It took a whopping three hours for everything.  I want my money back but, most of all, my time.  DO NOT GO HERE unless you like taking three to four hours for one meal.
author: Victoria P.

description: Came here for a company dinner tonight. We ordered a variety of appetizers for the table to share and then everyone ordered entrees and a few desserts. Honestly, every bite I had tonight was amazing. Balanced, comforting, delicious.  Not a bad dish was served. My favorite app was the deviled eggs which I'm still thinking about. The service was friendly and very responsive. I travel a lot for work but if I'm back in SFO, I'll be stopping by this place.
author: Doug U.

description:
SO GOOD! And so friendly. Loved it. Had the steak and I've never had anything like that before and the staff was so nice and attentive. 
Felt at home.  A+++ on the food, ambiance and friendliness and it's super cute inside
author: Amanda R.

description:
Glad to read Aquitaine is still alive & kicking... seeing as Dante's Weird Fish has moved on from this culinary plane. A guy leaves for six months and everything changes... But this review is all about fantastic French fare you can have on your lunch break. You deserve it. You work hard. Take a break. Have a glass of wine and revel in the thought of taking a jet plane to Paris. If you can't make that happen, Aquitaine is good for a quick respite.

Walking in, I was a bit shocked that I was in SF.* Being so close to the Financial District, I was surprised to discover such a laid back, European vibe. People didn't seem to be in a hurry. Wine was freely flowing at lunch time and I observed people in the act of prolonged conversation, not hurried scarfing of food. I can get down with this. Our waiter came to the table and asked what wine we wanted. Well, don't mind if I do. I can get used to this kind of living. Not wanting to go too rogue (I was on a work trip and had some newer hires with me. Drinking to the point of sobbing might not be a good look), I decided on a negrette rose and I was off the the Euro races.

Since I was going all in to my French experience, I decided to speak in Franglais, mangle my 'ouis' with 'sis' (living in Miami confused my French) and each all things decadent and heavy-ish. I chose a cod salad to start with. It was a pleasant surprise. Big pieces of breaded/fried cod sat atop a mound of lightly-dressed greens, tomatoes, herbs, olives, and artichokes. Not only was it a wonderful way in which to start my meal, I felt quite fancy eating it. Since I was going for 'light-ish', my main was a sandwich (salad and sandwich is a respectable lunch). But because I was enjoying from French decadence, said sandwich was a duck confit reuben. I'm not a fan of the typical reuben but add duck confit to most anything and I'll eat it. The sandwich was no different. It was sinful in its excess. The duck confit melted in my mouth. Topped with remoulade and pickled onions, every bite was an ode to joy. The pastrami and swiss - while stalwarts of the reuben - seemed to get in the way of the awesomeness of the sandwich. I understand why they were (essential) elements but I wouldn't have missed them if they were gone. 

I entered Aquitaine not quite sure of what I was getting into. I left a fan eager to return. Wine for lunch makes everything awesome!

*I shouldn't have been. SF is a food lover's paradise. Everything's here and the majority of it is really really good.
author: Johnny T.
